I wear glasses and it’s completely fine. There is a spacer included if you have big glasses, and you can also order special prescription lenses if you want.
I think it's easily the best $200 tech purchase you can make right now, especially if you've been wanting to try out VR.

It's so nice to have it on your desk, pick it up and instantly be in VR within 3 seconds. I'm also excited at the possibility of using it on planes with my noise cancelling headphones to completely escape and watch Netflix in a VR log cabin.
I haven't noticed any annoying drift. Have to reset the controller a few times when switching apps, but that's it. I'm excited to use it to watch Netflix on a plane with noise cancelling headphones.

The strap system is great and I haven't felt the weight to be a problem at all. It's 3DoF and the tracking is fantastic. It *does* have built-in sound, which projects backwards from the headset - spatial audio is great. Others can hear it though, so 3.5mm jack also included.
I'm really excited about the WebVR potential for this thing... it runs all the demos I could find perfectly in its built-in browser.

I feel like the optics are on par with the Vive, yep. Field of view might be slightly lower. Obviously the apps you're running won't be as visually advanced as something you'd run on a gaming machine. The built in spatial sound is also really cool on this thing.
The experience with Oculus Go is immersive enough that I feel comfortable spending a lot of time in it.
You mean live streams? I do them on YouTube.
Oh how's Land's End? Was thinking of buying that. I've been playing Rush and Bait a lot.

I've never owned a headset personally, but have used Rift/Vives a lot over the years (incl. the VR World in Japan, which is amazing). At $200, there is no excuse to not jump in with this thing. I've been using it daily, it's so convenient.
(PS. Yes I know they're owned by Facebook but I'm just limiting my data footprint and what I share. It's worth it for this hardware)
If you've ever wanted to try out VR but don't have a powerful computer, or are a developer and want to try out VR dev (incl. WebVR which is supported) I highly recommend this thing.

Pros: - Great optics, better than the Rift in my experience - Processor is snappy and hasn't lagged for me (yet) - Setup is a breeze - 3 hour battery is impressive The only Con I see is the software library still feeling a little limited. But I think this $200 unit will fix that

I personally picked up the 64gb model, as the storage space required stacks up quickly as you install some of the bigger titles that are more than just tech demos. https://amzn.to/2IgTYJA  It's unreal to instantly be in VR the second you put this cable-free thing on your head.

I ended up buckling and buying the Oculus Go because they have a better software library than Google Daydream right now... wow, this thing shouldn't be as good as it is for $200. I've been a skeptic for so long but really think this could be the beginning of VR going mainstream.
